body:
Sorry, but I'm afraid the answer to this is still no. It keeps coming up every so often, and the stance hasn't changed, AFAICT: we already support 2 build systems and are not willing to support more of them.

I'm sorry, but we'll never please everyone, I'm afraid.

FWIW, I'm investigating switching the node.js build system to cmake for $reasons, with the preliminary work available in https://github.com/bnoordhuis/io.js/commits/cmake.

Maybe in the fullness of time libuv can make the switch as well and dump the GYP build.  Almost certainly no sooner than v2, though.

@bnoordhuis That's interesting! :-) So, I've used a bit of CMake myself, but I've seen a bunch of libuv CMake scripts which are pretty complex, if we can have something simple we can give it a try.

@roxlu Do you volunteer to write / maintain that? (once written it shouldn't require much maintenance...)
@saghul yes I'm up for that for sure.
@roxlu kewl! I see @bnoordhuis wrote some cmake file already, but that doesn't include tests nor static / shared builds AFAIK, feel free to open a PR and let's see!
Looks pretty complete, thanks for the pointer!

I've just got out of `uvw` (that is a `cmake` based project) the stuff used to import `libuv`.
[This](https://github.com/skypjack/libuv_cmake) is the repository where I put a self contained example.
It shouldn't be difficult to maintain, it's not invasive and... well, it just works.
I'm not sure this is the best way to do that, but I found it pretty easy to use and with a few pros I like definitely.
For the topic is _Add CMake support_, I'd say it matches the requirements and it's worth mentioning it.
The good part is that it doesn't _replicate_ somehow the build system of `libuv` and files are not listed explicitly. It downloads and compiles `libuv` as an external dependency and updates it whenever the user runs `cmake`. This should reduce the time spent to maintain the two projects aligned. Unless headers are moved around, build chain is changed or you decide to wipe out the `.libs` directory, it won't require any change to work.
Yeah, I'm lazy, but can you blame me?
Thank you @roxlu for bringing this up! It blows my mind this project doesn't have a CMake build system. I'd also volunteer to maintain this build system, I love CMake!
@saghul - we....means everyone?. I guess the support for CMake has been provided ie the work has been done. This is opensource right?
